title: Dev Toolbox
summary: A mobile-first, self-hosted developer environment built to make real software development possible on the go — with context, planning, editing, and reasoning all in one place.
problem: There are very few good coding environments for mobile. And I kept exceeding the limits of the free-tier plan on Replit.
context: Dev Toolbox started as a response to a simple frustration: coding on the go just wasn’t feasible. I wanted something that would let me work wherever I was — with real context, real tools, and a workflow that didn’t fall apart outside a desktop setup, and didn't charge me monthly.
solution: I designed and built a self-hosted, mobile-first environment centered on the essentials: a clean file editor, integrated logging, and an innovative block selector for working with code blocks. Over time it expanded with GitHub and Trello integration, project planning tools, and an AI context packet downloader — all unified into a single workspace that keeps reasoning close at hand.
innovations: Mobile-optimized code block selector for navigating and manipulating structured code
Integrated, always-visible structured logs and console output
Self-hosted GitHub integration for commits, diffs, and repository insights
Unified project planner with sprints, sessions, and context surfaces
AI context packet downloader for explainable, project-aware reasoning
impact: By bringing editing, planning, logs, GitHub, and project context together in one place, Dev Toolbox makes mobile development not just possible but productive. It reduces cognitive load, removes tool switching, and makes the entire workflow more structured, explainable, and portable.

title: Operations & Workflow Design
summary: Improving clarity, structure, and alignment in operational environments by shaping workflows, expectations, and communication loops.
problem: Teams were operating in high-variance environments with unclear expectations, uneven communication, and workflows that generated unnecessary friction and mistakes.
context: In operational and leadership roles, I was responsible for both outcomes and the systems that supported day-to-day work — how information flowed, how handoffs worked, and how people stayed aligned.
solution: Clarified expectations, redesigned workflows, created stable routines, and coached people through transitions. Focused on reducing ambiguity, strengthening communication loops, and making responsibilities visible at every level.
impact: Teams experienced fewer surprises, smoother handoffs, clearer responsibility boundaries, and more predictable day-to-day execution. The result was calmer operations and more trust in the system.
innovations: Introduced clear, stable workflows that reduced variance and improved day-to-day consistency
Designed communication loops that strengthened alignment across teams
Created structured expectations and responsibility boundaries to reduce ambiguity
Developed coaching frameworks that supported people through transitions and clarified roles

title: Finance Tools / Simplicity
summary: A budgeting and financial-tracking system designed for calm visibility and confident day-to-day money decisions.
problem: Most budgeting tools generate noise instead of clarity. They surface too much, too little, or the wrong information at the wrong moment — making it harder to understand what’s actually happening with your money.
context: Built as a real-world system to support monthly planning, recurring bills, flexible spending, and daily decision-making with as little friction as possible.
solution: Created a calm, mobile-first budgeting environment that highlights what matters: upcoming obligations, category health, patterns, and day-to-day occurrences. The flow is designed to stay honest, predictable, and easy to revisit.
impact: Simplicity supports more confident financial decisions by surfacing the right information at the right time, giving users a grounded sense of where they stand and what needs attention.
innovations: A calm, mobile-first budgeting interface focused on clarity rather than noise
Daily and monthly workflows built around real financial behavior instead of abstract categories
A predictable, honest model for obligations, category health, and recurring patterns
A review flow that keeps new transactions organized without overwhelming the user

title: Aurora
summary: A conceptual approach to building software through conversation, centered on intent, understanding, and transparent results.
problem: Software creation today is fragmented across documents, tools, and communication channels, making it difficult to maintain clarity and shared understanding.
context: Aurora emerged from years of operational work and independent software development, shaped by questions around clarity, communication, and how people naturally express intent.
solution: Explores a conversational workflow where people express what they want, the system reflects its understanding, and results evolve through shared reasoning — without revealing technical mechanisms, schema, or internals.
innovations: A conceptual approach to software shaped through conversation instead of traditional development steps
A workflow centered on intent → understanding → result, emphasizing clarity and shared reasoning
An exploration of explainability as a foundational property of software creation
A vision for more natural, transparent human–AI collaboration in shaping digital systems
impact: Provides a direction for future tools that prioritize clarity, explainability, and human-centered interaction with complex systems. Aurora is narrative-first, focused on concepts rather than implementation.
